ai_answer.explanation: Achondroplasia is autosomal dominant, but approximately 80% of cases are due to a new, sporadic mutation in a family with no prior history of the condition.

question: A girl with club foot at 3 months. No family history. Antenatal history insignificant. The condition greatly improved with physiotherapy.
official_answer: Option G. Multifactorial.

ai_answer.explanation: Isolated congenital talipes equinovarus (clubfoot) is considered a multifactorial disorder, resulting from an interaction of multiple genetic and environmental factors.

question: Newborn (?) with dyspnoea, tachypnoea, x-ray showed boot-shaped heart, investigation showed hypocalcaemia, CT showed thymic aplasia. ?Karyotyping/?chromosome study normal.
official_answer: Option F. Chromosomal (microscopic and submicroscopic). diGeorge = microdeletion.

ai_answer.explanation: DiGeorge syndrome is caused by a submicroscopic deletion on chromosome 22q11.2, which is a type of chromosomal abnormality not visible on standard karyotyping.

question: A 6-month-old boy, with unremarkable perinatal and postnatal history, was noticed by to have increasing lethargy and floppiness. He started breast feeding on day 2 of life and was discharged home. Physical exam showed a lethargic, floppy, jittery looking baby, tachycardia, and tachypnoea. No foci of infection was found. Emergency department did ABG. pH 7.25, pCO2 3.5, HCO3 10.0, Base excess -10. Na, K normal. Urea, creatinine low. He was admitted to NICU with the following investigations results. Hb 15.0, WBC 3 x 10^9, ANC 0.6, Platelet 100, Blood glucose 2.9mmol/L. CXR and AXR are normal. Urine LE nitrite negative. Urinalysis ketones 2+, glucose negative, protein negative, pH 5.5. (a) Give two differential diagnoses. (2 marks). (b) What is the arterial blood gas abnormality (2 marks). (c) What 4 further investigations would you order? (2 marks). (d) Give 4 immediate management plan. (4 marks).
official_answer:
(a) Inborn error of metabolism (IEM), drug intoxication, electrolyte disturbances, DKA.
(b) Metabolic acidosis with partial respiratory compensation.
(c) LFT, CK, IEM kit (serum ammonia, lactate), serum ketone, random cortisol, GH.
(d) IV dextrose infusion (DKI drip), consult pediatric endocrinology/chemical pathology, oxygen support, rehydration, and close monitoring of vital signs.

ai_answer.explanation: The presentation of ketotic hypoglycemia with severe metabolic acidosis in an infant strongly suggests an inborn error of metabolism, and the proposed diagnostic and management steps are appropriate.

question: The following is least suggestive of inborn errors of metabolism:
options: Early unexplained neonatal deaths in the family.
official_answer: Option B. Baby jaundiced at day 3. This is likely physiological.

ai_answer.explanation: Physiological jaundice is a very common and benign condition in newborns, whereas all other options are significant red flags for a potential inborn error of metabolism.

question: A 10-year-old boy, hypoglycaemia after fasting for 4 hours. What is the most likely condition?
official_answer: Option B. Glycogenosis.

ai_answer.explanation: Hypoglycemia after a short fast (2.5-12 hours) is characteristic of glycogen storage diseases due to the inability to properly mobilize glucose from glycogen stores.

question: A 3-month-old boy was brought to the hospital A&E department by the mother who reported his son fell from his cot the day before and sustained some bruises on his face. On examination, there were bruises of different ages on his face and lower legs. His nutritional state was poor. He appeared dirty and did not seem to move his right arm as well as his left. The rest of the examination was normal. His mother is a single 20-year-old woman living with her own mother. (a) What are the differential diagnoses? (b) Outline your management for the most likely diagnosis.
official_answer:
(a) DDx 1: Physical child abuse and neglect. DDx 2: Coagulation disorder. DDx 3: True accidental injury.
(b) Management involves further history taking, a thorough physical examination for hidden injuries, investigations including a skeletal survey and coagulation profile, and psychosocial management. This includes informing the medical coordinator, consulting the Medical Social Worker (MSW) and child protection services, notifying the police, and arranging a multidisciplinary case conference to ensure the child's welfare.

ai_answer.explanation: The history is inconsistent with the infant's developmental stage and the physical findings are highly suggestive of non-accidental injury, requiring a comprehensive medical and psychosocial management plan.

question: A 6-month-old child presented to the A&E Department for poor feeding. Mother had depression and started on anti-depressant since the third trimester. (b) Describe the abnormalities in the fundi. (2 marks) The baby suddenly had loss of consciousness. CT brain given with acute right subdural haematoma. (c) Describe the CT findings. (d) Considering the whole case, what is the most likely diagnosis? (e) The girl is finally discharge with follow-up arranged. During the follow-up visit, the girl is found to have developmental delay. Which of the following milestones are abnormal? (Circle the correct answer) • Crawling with 4 limbs at 9 months onwards Normal / Abnormal • Speak first single word at 12 months onwards Normal / Abnormal • Stand without support at 15 months onwards Normal / Abnormal • Walk independently at 20 months onwards Normal / Abnormal
official_answer:
(a) Complete blood count for thrombocytopenia.
(b) Retinal haemorrhage, papilloedema.
(c) Acute right subdural haematoma, with midline shift, obliterated ventricle, cerebral oedema (effacement of the sulci).
(d) Child abuse and shaken baby syndrome.
(e) Crawling at 9 months: Normal. Speak first word at 12 months: Normal. Stand without support at 15 months: Normal. Walk independently at 20 months: Abnormal.

ai_answer.explanation: The clinical triad of subdural hematoma, retinal hemorrhages, and encephalopathy is pathognomonic for abusive head trauma, and the developmental assessment correctly identifies walking at 20 months as abnormal.

question: A 3-year-old girl was admitted with vaginal bleeding. Her mother claimed that she slipped and fell onto sharp plastic toys that morning. question: 1-year-old with good past health presented with apparent life threatening event for 5 minutes. Mum attempt mouth-to-mouth blowing. The baby appeared ill-looking and drowsy. question: A 6-month-old boy presented to A&E with vomiting for 1 day. Irritable with inconsolable cry. Afebrile with no localising symptom. Bilateral retinal haemorrhage. What is the most likely diagnosis?

question: A 16-year-old girl who has been hospitalized in the past for attempted suicide, presents with epigastric pain and admits to taking an unknown number of tablets of paracetamol. She is admitted to the pediatric ward for treatment. (a) Describe how you will manage her during this acute episode. (b) Describe how you would conduct the psychosocial interview with this adolescent. (c) Describe what resources you can mobilize to prevent her from further attempting suicide.
official_answer:
(a) Acute management includes ABCs, monitoring, investigations (serum paracetamol, L/RFT, clotting), activated charcoal if within 1 hour, and N-acetylcysteine (NAC) guided by the Rumack-Matthew nomogram.
(b) A psychosocial interview should be conducted using a framework like HEADSS (Home, Education, Activities, Drugs, Sex, Suicide) to explore risk and protective factors.
(c) Resources to mobilize include a Medical Social Worker (MSW), a psychiatrist for formal assessment and management of underlying mental health issues, and developing a safety plan with the patient and family.

ai_answer.explanation: The management plan correctly follows standard protocol, addressing immediate medical stabilization for paracetamol toxicity followed by a comprehensive psychosocial assessment and multidisciplinary support for suicide prevention.

question: A 16-year-old girl taken unknown amount to Panadol. She had a history of cutting wrist razor blade. (a) What is the initial management of her condition? (b) How would you conduct an psychological interview with this girl?
official_answer:

(b) A psychological interview should establish rapport and use the HEADSS framework to assess her psychosocial situation and suicide risk.

question: Question on paracetamol overdose.

question: A 16-year-old girl is admitted for paracetamol overdose (10 tablets). (a) What is the initial management? official_answer:

question: A teenage girl is found to have strong alcoholic smell, ketamine was found. Conscious and stable. Evasive when taking history. (a) What is your acute management? (4 marks) (b) How do you take social history from this patient? (4 marks) (c) This patient complaints of chronic epigastric pain a few months later. How would you manage? (2 marks)
official_answer:
(a) Acute management: Maintain ABCs, monitor vitals, obtain IV access, check glucose and run toxicology screen. Provide supportive care. Give thiamine before dextrose if considering alcohol intoxication. Refer to psychiatry for substance abuse management.
(b) Social history: Use the HEADSS framework to explore her home life, education, activities, drug use, sexuality, and suicide/mood history.
(c) Chronic epigastric pain: This could be psychosomatic due to depression or a physical issue like PUD. ai_answer.explanation: This response correctly outlines the management of acute polydrug intoxication, the use of a structured tool for psychosocial history, and the approach to subsequent psychosomatic complaints.

question: A teenage girl found to be 'behaving abnormally' on street, complained of seeing something should not be seen, slurring of speech and cannot tell address. official_answer:

options: Sit with support with a round back

ai_answer.explanation: While sitting with a round back and inability to speak in sentences are age-appropriate for a 6-month-old, nasal flaring is a sign of significant respiratory distress and increased work of breathing.

question: Patient presents with drooling saliva and looks toxic (epiglotitis picture). What is your immediate management?
options: Urgent airway assessment in operation theatre
Urgent airway assessment with neck x-ray
official_answer: Option A. any IV puncture may cause airway to close. secure airway first by escorting patient to OT with tracheostomy kit ready THEN secure IV access before intubation. neck X-ray wastes time and does not give information on airway.

ai_answer.explanation: In suspected epiglottitis, the paramount priority is to secure the airway in a controlled environment like an operating theatre, as any distress or procedure can precipitate complete airway obstruction.

question: A 5-month-old boy, 25th centile weight. has moderately severe OSA. On examination, there are bilateral kissing tonsils and mildly swollen inferior turbinates. Sleeping study shows apnoea-hypnoea index 5.x. What is the first-line treatment for him?
official_answer: Option A. The tonsils are already kissing! The patient already has severe OSA which is an absolute indication for adenoidectomy.

ai_answer.explanation: Adenotonsillar hypertrophy, especially 'kissing tonsils', is the most common cause of pediatric OSA, making adenotonsillectomy the definitive first-line treatment.

question: A 5-year-old girl presents with fever for 2 days and shortness of breath for a few hours. Her mother has been giving her frequent doses of antipyretics for the fever. Examination reveals mild tachypnoea but good and symmetrical breath sound with no adventitious sounds.
official_answer: Option J. Hallmarks of acute salicylate overdose are hyperpnea, tachypnoea, metabolic acidosis and tachycardia.

ai_answer.explanation: Salicylate (aspirin) toxicity classically causes a respiratory alkalosis from direct stimulation of the respiratory center, leading to tachypnea, often without lung findings.

question: A 2-year-old boy has high swinging fever and productive cough for 5 days. He also has shortness of breath and poor appetite for 1 day. Examination reveals subcostal insucking, mild cyanosis and diffuse crepitations over both lungs.
official_answer: Option I.

ai_answer.explanation: The combination of high fever, productive cough, and signs of respiratory distress with diffuse crepitations on auscultation is characteristic of pneumonia.

question: A 3-year-old girl presents with coryzal symptoms and fever for 3 days followed by progressive shortness of breath. Examination reveals poor peripheral circulation and weak pulses. The cardiac apex is displaced laterally and the liver is enlarged to 4 cm below the costal margin. There are crepitations over both lung bases.
official_answer: Option H. RV and LV failure symptoms and signs. Displaced apex due to dilated cardiomyopathy caused by infective damage.

ai_answer.explanation: The presentation of heart failure (displaced apex, hepatomegaly, poor perfusion, crepitations) following a viral prodrome is classic for acute myocarditis.

question: A 9-year-old boy presents with recurrent vomiting and abdominal pain for 1 day. He also has progressive weight loss, malaise and polyuria in the past 4 weeks. Physical examination reveals significant dehydration, deep and rapid breathing.
official_answer: Option F.

ai_answer.explanation: The subacute history of polyuria and weight loss culminating in dehydration and deep, rapid (Kussmaul) breathing is the classic presentation of diabetic ketoacidosis.

question: A newborn infant presents with tachypnoea and cyanosis at birth. Physical examination reveals a scaphoid abdomen with decreased breath sounds over the left side of the chest.
official_answer: Option C.

ai_answer.explanation: Respiratory distress at birth combined with a scaphoid abdomen and unilateral decreased breath sounds is the hallmark of a congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

question: 6 months old, wheezing.
official_answer: Option D.

ai_answer.explanation: Wheezing in an infant under one year of age, especially during winter months, is most commonly caused by acute bronchiolitis.

question: 4 years old, drooling of saliva, sitting in forward leaning position, fever for 1 day, 40.1°C.
official_answer: Option B.

ai_answer.explanation: The tripod position (sitting forward), drooling, and high fever are classic signs of acute epiglottitis, a medical emergency.

question: Right lower zone crackles.
official_answer: Option A.

ai_answer.explanation: Localized crackles (crepitations) in a specific lung zone are a key physical finding for focal pneumonia.

question: A 6-week-old baby, decreased feeding, dry cough, dirty eye discharge, in respiratory distress. P/E: pink, tachypneic, respiratory rate 60/min, subcostal insucking, breath sound is symmetrical and vesicular, diffuse fine crackles. Both eyes with conjunctivitis and yellow discharge. ai_answer.explanation: The combination of afebrile pneumonia and conjunctivitis in a neonate (4-12 weeks old) is characteristic of Chlamydia trachomatis infection acquired during birth.

question: A 3-year-old girl. Bouts of cough after left alone to play in her room. Previously well and immunization up-to-date. Cough persists, cannot sleep. P/E: pink, mild respiratory distress, RR 40/min. Right chest hyperinflation with decreased breath sound. Apex is located at 4th intercostal space 1 cm lateral to mid-clavicular line.
official_answer: Option H. FB aspiration more likely to be a/w air-trapping due to ball-valve effect.

ai_answer.explanation: The sudden onset of cough in a previously well toddler, coupled with unilateral signs of air trapping (hyperinflation and decreased breath sounds), is highly suspicious for foreign body inhalation.

question: A 2-week-old baby girl. Repeated cough, refuse feeding. Low grade fever of 38°C. Elder brother just recovered from viral URTI. P/E: respiratory distress, thick nasal discharge. RR 60/min irregular. Chest hyperinflated, diffuse expiratory rhonchi, coarse crackles. Occasional brief apnoeic episodes.
official_answer: Option I.

ai_answer.explanation: This clinical picture of a young infant with URTI symptoms, respiratory distress, wheezing/rhonchi, and a sick contact is classic for bronchiolitis, most commonly caused by RSV.

question: Respiratory distress, wheezing, history of eczema.
official_answer: Option C.

ai_answer.explanation: The combination of wheezing and a personal history of atopy (eczema) strongly suggests a diagnosis of asthma.

question: Stridor during feeding and crying only.
official_answer: Option G. classical, esp exacerbated on supine.

ai_answer.explanation: Inspiratory stridor in an infant that worsens with activities that increase airflow, such as feeding or crying, is the classic presentation of laryngomalacia.

question: A 3-year-old boy with croupy cough and respiratory distress.
official_answer: Option B. Mild croup: single dose of oral dexamethasone (0.6 mg/kg). Moderate to severe croup: administration of humidified air or oxygen + nebulized epinephrine + dexamethasone.

ai_answer.explanation: Corticosteroids (oral, inhaled, or intramuscular) are the cornerstone of management for croup as they reduce airway inflammation and edema.

question: A 1-year-old boy with bronchiolitis.
official_answer: Option J. Children with moderate to severe respiratory distress requires hospitalization for supportive care and monitoring. A trial of inhaled bronchodilators is suggested. Oral bronchodilators, systemic steroids, antibiotics and nebulized hypertonic saline are NOT suggested to be used routinely.

ai_answer.explanation: The management of bronchiolitis is primarily supportive, focusing on hydration, nutritional support, and supplemental oxygen as needed.

question: Wheezy attack after vigorous exercise.
official_answer: Option C. for acute wheeze.

ai_answer.explanation: Exercise-induced bronchoconstriction is treated with a short-acting inhaled bronchodilator (like albuterol) taken shortly before exercise or to relieve acute symptoms.

question: F/?, acute otitis media.
official_answer: Option A. Management of AOM. When to give antibiotics? All <2 yo, or >=2 years old who appear toxic/have persistent otalgia for more than 48 hours / temperature >39°C / bilateral AOM / unreliable followup.

ai_answer.explanation: Acute otitis media is a bacterial infection of the middle ear, and antibiotics such as amoxicillin are the first-line treatment, especially in younger children or those with severe symptoms.

question: M/?, history of asthma, nocturnal symptoms even with inhaled bronchodilator every night.
official_answer: Option B. Partly controlled asthma with inhaled bronchodilator (SABA?/step 1). Low dose inhaled ICS is indicated (step up).

ai_answer.explanation: Persistent nocturnal symptoms despite as-needed bronchodilator use indicate poorly controlled asthma, requiring the addition of a daily controller medication like an inhaled steroid.

question: A 2-year-old child presented with one day history of stridor of acute onset and barking cough. There were no coryzal symptoms. The child was not tachypneic and the oxygen saturation was 95%. low grade fever.
official_answer: Option A/B? (More history is needed).

ai_answer.explanation: The acute onset of stridor and barking cough with low-grade fever is the classic presentation of viral croup (laryngotracheitis).

question: Acute stridor, high grade fever. Look toxic. Muffled voice.
official_answer: Option C.

ai_answer.explanation: The combination of acute stridor, high fever, a toxic appearance, and a muffled ('hot potato') voice is highly indicative of acute epiglottitis.

question: Acute stridor, high grade fever. Had neck stiffness.
official_answer: Option D.

ai_answer.explanation: Neck stiffness with stridor and fever suggests a deep neck space infection, such as a retropharyngeal abscess, which can compress the airway.

question: Stridor occurs after ingestion of peanut. Associated with swelling of both eyes.
official_answer: Option G.

ai_answer.explanation: The acute onset of stridor and periorbital swelling immediately following ingestion of a known allergen like peanuts is characteristic of anaphylaxis-induced angioedema.

question: Stridor occurs after ingestion of peanut.
official_answer: Option F.

ai_answer.explanation: Sudden onset of stridor while eating, particularly with items like peanuts, is highly suspicious for an aspirated foreign body lodged in the upper airway.

question: 8/M recurrent sneezing in the morning. No nasal obstruction. P/E showed mildly swollen inferior nasal tubinates.
official_answer: Option B.

ai_answer.explanation: For mild allergic rhinitis characterized by sneezing, a non-sedating second-generation antihistamine is the preferred first-line pharmacological treatment.

question: A 4-year-old boy presented with coughing for 2 months, every 4–5 am. He had 3 days of febrile illness 1 month ago. Physical examination was normal.
official_answer: Option F.

ai_answer.explanation: Chronic, nocturnal, or early morning cough, often following a viral trigger, is a classic presentation of cough-variant asthma in children.

question: A 1-month-old baby had breathing difficulties since discharge from hospital. He did not have any fever. Physical examination showed diffuse wheezing and crepitations more prominent on right side.
official_answer: Option E. Reflux of gastric contents through the TEF results in aspiration pneumonia → right lower lobe.

ai_answer.explanation: Persistent respiratory symptoms from birth, especially with signs of aspiration pneumonia (wheezing/crepitations), are suspicious for a congenital anomaly like a tracheo-oesophageal fistula.

question: A 4-year-old girl had cough for 2 months, sometimes slightly feverish. CXR showed prominent right hilar lymph nodes.
official_answer: Option G.

ai_answer.explanation: A chronic cough with low-grade fevers and the finding of hilar lymphadenopathy on chest X-ray is the classic presentation of primary pulmonary tuberculosis.

question: A 4-month-old baby had cough for 2 days and was slight feverish. Physical examination showed respiratory distress, diffuse wheezing and crepitations.
official_answer: Option A.

ai_answer.explanation: The acute onset of cough, respiratory distress, and diffuse wheezing in an infant during winter months is the hallmark of acute bronchiolitis.

question: Boy with stridor whenever crying.
official_answer: Option D.

ai_answer.explanation: Intermittent inspiratory stridor in an infant that is exacerbated by increased respiratory effort (like crying) is characteristic of laryngomalacia.

question: A 12-year-old boy complains of pain in the his right hip and knee which has lasted for the past 6 weeks. He also complains of ache over the dorsum of the right foot. He is afebrile and otherwise well. Physical examination reveals a slightly swollen right knee and there is decreased ROM for both of the right hip and knee joint. (a) What are the differential diagnoses? (b) Outline the investigation to establish the diagnosis. (c) Outline the management for the most likely diagnosis.
official_answer: (a) Differential diagnoses: Enthesitis-related JIA, Pauci-articular onset JIA, Trauma/overuse, Haemophilia, Chronic infection (e.g., TB), Reactive arthritis, Bone tumour. (b) Investigations: Bloods (CBP, ESR, CRP, RF, HLA-B27, ANA), X-ray of hip and knee, Joint aspiration for cell count and culture. (c) Management: Rest, pain relief (NSAIDs), physiotherapy, and potentially DMARDs (e.g., methotrexate) or biologics if refractory. Refer to ophthalmology to screen for uveitis.

ai_answer.explanation: The presentation of oligoarthritis in a boy over 6 with lower limb and entheseal involvement is highly suggestive of enthesitis-related arthritis, a subtype of JIA.

question: 2-year-old boy, spiking fever and salmon-pink skin rash, ESR 100. (a) Differential diagnosis? Investigation? (b) He subsequent developed multiple joint pain for 6 weeks. Most likely diagnosis? Management plan? (c) Counseling the parents about the prognosis.
official_answer: (a) DDx: Systemic onset JIA, infections (viral exanthems, Kawasaki disease), malignancy (leukemia). Ix: CBC (leukocytosis, thrombocytosis), ESR/CRP, ferritin, blood cultures. (b) Diagnosis: Systemic onset JIA. Management: NSAIDs, then steroids or biologics (anti-IL-1, anti-IL-6) for severe/refractory disease. (c) Prognosis: Variable course (monophasic, polycyclic, or persistent); risk of macrophage activation syndrome (MAS); about half will have persistent arthritis.

ai_answer.explanation: The classic triad of daily spiking fevers, an evanescent salmon-pink rash, and arthritis is pathognomonic for Systemic Onset Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (sJIA).

question: A 8-year-old boy with swollen knee and limping for 2 weeks. There is no fever. Child later develops pain over the sole of the foot, with decreased range of movement over the knee joint. On more detailed history taking, the boy's father also had history of knee pain during adolescence and recently developed back pain. (a) What are the differential diagnoses? (b) What is the likely diagnosis? How would you investigate? (c) Briefly outline your management. (d) How would you counsel him and his son?
official_answer: (a) DDx: Septic arthritis, Trauma, JIA, Osteosarcoma. (b) Likely Diagnosis: Enthesitis-related JIA. Investigations: HLA-B27, RF, ANA, CRP, ESR, CBC. X-ray of knee and pelvis. (c) Management: Multidisciplinary care, NSAIDs, local steroid injections, DMARDs (methotrexate), and anti-TNF agents if refractory. (d) Counseling: Discuss the genetic link with HLA-B27 and the increased risk of developing spondyloarthropathy in adulthood, though it is not a certainty.

ai_answer.explanation: The combination of arthritis, enthesitis (pain at tendon insertion, e.g., sole of foot), and a family history of spondyloarthropathy in a male child is characteristic of Enthesitis-Related Arthritis (ERA).

question:
A 12-month-old boy with known history of tetralogy of Fallot presents with shortness of breath, worsening of cyanosis. He seems lethargic.
(a) What are the four cardiac abnormalities of tetralogy of Fallot? (4 marks)
(b) What is the cause of the acute problem? (2 marks)
(c) What is the acute and long term management and prognosis of the child? (4 marks)
official_answer:
(a) RVH, large VSD, overriding aorta, pulmonary infundibular stenosis
(b) Cyanotic spell; sudden decrease in peripheral vascular resistance, increased right-to-left shunt
(c) Acute: calm the baby to stop the vicious cycle / put the baby in a knee-chest position / propranolol, O2, morphine. Chronic: patch closure of VSD and enlargement of RV outflow obstruction; Blalock-Taussig shunt in medical refractory hyper cyanotic spell; oral propranolol as prophylaxis. Prognosis: good? but may recur without corrective surgery?

ai_answer.explanation: The answer correctly identifies the four classic components of TOF, the pathophysiology of a tet spell, and the standard acute and long-term management strategies.

question:
While playing football, a 12-year-old boy suddenly collapsed. No carotid pulse, no breathing. Paramedics CPR and attached cardiac monitor. (ECG shown, QT 541 ms/QTc 564 ms.)
(a) What is the abnormality? (1 mark)
(b) What is the immediate treatment? (1 mark)
(c) What is the abnormality? (1 mark)
(d) What is the mode of inheritance? (1 mark)
(e) What is the diagnosis? (2 marks)
(f) Name 2 other possible causes of the ECG. (2 marks)
(g) What are the 2 important management aspects for the patient in long-term? (2 marks)
official_answer:
(a) Torsades de pointes
(b) MgSO4, overdrive pacing DC shock
(c) Long QT
(d) Autosomal dominant
(e) ?Long QT syndrome
(f) Electrolyte disturbance (hypoK, hypoCa, hypoMg)
(g) ICD implantation, beta-blocker, genetic counselling

ai_answer.explanation: The ECG shows polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (Torsades de Pointes) in the context of a prolonged QTc, with management correctly focused on magnesium, defibrillation, and long-term prevention with beta-blockers and an ICD.

question: A 4-year-old boy presents with a heart murmur. Cardiovascular examination reveals normal peripheral pulses, normally located apex beat, mild parasternal heave, widely-split second heart sound with diminished intensity of the pulmonic component, and a grade 3/6 ejection systolic murmur at the left upper sternal border. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
options: Ventricular septal defect and pulmonary hypertension
official_answer: Option C. The answer key discusses B/C, but notes that a diminished P2 is characteristic of pulmonary stenosis, whereas in ASD it is normal or loud.

ai_answer.explanation: The combination of a widely-split S2 with a diminished P2 component and an ejection systolic murmur at the left upper sternal border is classic for valvular pulmonary stenosis.

question: A 7-year-old boy was diagnosed to have Kawasaki disease 3 years previously. He is noted to have bilateral coronary arterial aneurysms that have persisted on follow-up. There is chest pain on exertion. Cardiovascular examination is completely normal. Apart from the aneurysms, echocardiogram reveals no other abnormalities. He is scheduled to have dental extraction tomorrow. Which of the following is the most appropriate suggestion to the dentist?
options: Give oral amoxicillin 1 hour prior to dental extraction.
Give oral amoxicillin 1 hour before and 6 hours after dental extraction.
Give intravenous ampicillin immediately before dental extraction.
Give intravenous ampicillin and gentamicin immediately before dental extraction.
Antibiotic prophylaxis against bacterial endocarditis is not required.
official_answer: Option E. According to NICE guidelines CG64, coronary arterial aneurysm does not pose an adult or children with increase risk of IE.

ai_answer.explanation: Current guidelines for infective endocarditis prophylaxis do not include coronary artery aneurysms post-Kawasaki disease as a high-risk condition requiring antibiotics for dental procedures.

question: A boy with tetralogy of Fallot. What is the most likely?
official_answer: Option E. Hypercyanotic spells present as periods of profound cyanosis that occur because of episodes of almost total RVOT obstruction.

ai_answer.explanation: Hypercyanotic (tet) spells are a classic and life-threatening complication of unrepaired Tetralogy of Fallot due to dynamic right ventricular outflow tract obstruction.

question: An 8-year-old male with known history of heart disease falls down in street. He has poor capillary refill and ECG shows irregular wide QRS complexes. The most appropriate action is:
official_answer: Option B.

ai_answer.explanation: A patient in cardiac arrest with a wide complex tachycardia (a shockable rhythm like pulseless VT or VF) requires immediate defibrillation and high-quality CPR.

question: A young child with known small VSD is admitted with fever and cough. Pansystolic murmur, apex not displaced, throat congested. What is the most likely diagnosis?
official_answer: Option C. Fever in children with congenital heart disease: IE or recurrent respiratory infection. Given the cough and congested throat, URTI is most likely.

ai_answer.explanation: While infective endocarditis is a concern in children with VSD, the presence of specific respiratory symptoms like cough and throat congestion makes a common upper respiratory tract infection the most probable diagnosis.

question: A male adolescent presents with loss of conscious during a basketball game. Family history of sudden death during exertion. Physical examination shows strong apical impulse and loud murmur. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
official_answer: Option B. HOCM, coronary artery abnormalities and inherited arrhythmia are inheritable causes of sudden cardiac death. Exercise-induced, likely HOCM.

ai_answer.explanation: Exertional syncope combined with a family history of sudden death and a strong apical impulse are classic features of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HOCM).

question: Which of the followings is the commonest cause of heart failure in a 3-month-old child?
official_answer: Option C.

ai_answer.explanation: Ventricular septal defect is the most common congenital heart defect and a leading cause of heart failure in infancy as pulmonary vascular resistance falls post-birth.

question: A baby boy was found to be cyanotic 2 hours after birth. The cardiovascular examination revealed normal peripheral pulses, a strong right ventricular impulse, a single second heart sound, and a soft systolic murmur at the lower sternal border. The chest X-ray showed oligaemic lung fields and absence of thymic shadow. What is the most likely cardiac diagnosis?
options: Persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn
Pulmonary atresia and ventricular septal defect
official_answer: Option D. Cyanosis, RV pressure overload, single S2 (no blood through PA), no specific murmur. Absent thymic shadow suggests a conotruncal abnormality like DiGeorge syndrome.

ai_answer.explanation: The combination of severe cyanosis from birth, a single S2 (from an atretic pulmonary valve), and oligaemic lung fields strongly suggests a diagnosis of pulmonary atresia.

question: A mother of a child with an atrial septal defect (ASD) wants to know about antibiotic prophylaxis for dental extraction. What is the correct advice?
options: Prophylaxis is only required if the defect is large.
Prophylaxis is only required if there is associated valve disease.
official_answer: Antibiotic prophylaxis is not needed. According to 'Unique Features of Infective Endocarditis in Childhood' from Circulation 2002 Ferrieri et al. 'Conversely, in secundum atrial septal defect, in which shunting is not associated with high-velocity jet flow... endocarditis is not likely to occur.'

ai_answer.explanation: An isolated secundum atrial septal defect is considered a low-risk lesion for which infective endocarditis prophylaxis is not recommended under current guidelines.

question: Patient is tall, with lax joint, hypermobility and thoracic scoliosis. Now presents with bounding pulse, displaced apex and soft (2/6) diastolic murmur at LLSB. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
official_answer: Option A. The physical features are suggestive of Marfan syndrome, which is strongly associated with aortic root dilatation and subsequent aortic regurgitation.

ai_answer.explanation: The marfanoid habitus combined with a bounding pulse and an early diastolic murmur at the left lower sternal border are classic signs of aortic regurgitation.

question: A boy admitted. ECG shows SVT, narrow complex tachycardia. ATP infused, then ECG shows flutter wave with variable block, actually returned to SVT at the end of the strip. What is the diagnosis?
official_answer: Option B. The appearance of flutter waves after ATP (adenosine) administration is characteristic of atrial flutter, as the drug transiently blocks the AV node, unmasking the underlying atrial rhythm.

ai_answer.explanation: Adenosine (ATP) can unmask underlying atrial flutter by transiently blocking the AV node, which reveals the characteristic sawtooth flutter waves previously hidden by a 2:1 block.

question: A 12-year-old boy previously healthy, presented with shortness of breath for the recent two weeks. On examination: tachycardia/tachypnoea. Signs of right ventricular failure including hepatomegaly and lower leg oedema. Weak peripheral pulses. Displaced apex. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
official_answer: Option C. The presentation with signs of biventricular failure (displaced apex for LV failure, hepatomegaly/oedema for RV failure) is most compatible with dilated cardiomyopathy, often post-viral myocarditis.

ai_answer.explanation: The subacute presentation of biventricular heart failure in a previously healthy child is highly suggestive of dilated cardiomyopathy, which is frequently idiopathic or secondary to myocarditis.

question: Moderate cyanosis, 2/6 ejection systolic murmur at left upper sternal border, single second heart sound, finger clubbing.
official_answer: Option E. The combination of cyanosis, a single S2, an ejection systolic murmur, and clubbing are characteristic features of Tetralogy of Fallot.

ai_answer.explanation: This constellation of findings—cyanosis, single S2 (from an inaudible P2), ejection systolic murmur (from RVOT obstruction), and clubbing—is classic for Tetralogy of Fallot.

question: Wide split second heart sound, 3/6 ejection systolic murmur at left upper sternal border, mild heart deviation, no cyanosis.
official_answer: Option A/J. A or J depend on loudness of P2. The answer key indicates A/J, but a wide, fixed split S2 is pathognomonic for ASD.

ai_answer.explanation: A wide, fixed splitting of the second heart sound is the classic and pathognomonic auscultatory finding for an atrial septal defect (ASD).

question: 3/6 pansystolic murmur loudest at apex and radiates to axilla.
official_answer: Option C.

ai_answer.explanation: A pansystolic (holosystolic) murmur heard best at the apex and radiating to the axilla is the hallmark of mitral regurgitation (MR).

question: 3/6 pansystolic murmur loudest at left lower sternal border, deviated heart, pulsatile liver 3 cm below costal margin.
official_answer: Option D. Only D could give rise to a pulsatile liver.

ai_answer.explanation: A pansystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border with signs of right heart failure, such as a pulsatile liver, is characteristic of significant tricuspid regurgitation (TR).

question: 2/6 continuous murmur at right upper sternal border, decreases when lying supine.
official_answer: Option G. This describes a venous hum, which is a benign continuous murmur that changes with position and jugular vein compression.

ai_answer.explanation: A continuous murmur that diminishes when supine is the classic description of a benign venous hum, caused by turbulent flow in the jugular veins.

question: 4 days, poor feeding, tachypnoea, weak femoral pulses, cardiomegaly, hepatomegaly.
official_answer: Option H.

ai_answer.explanation: The presentation of heart failure with weak or absent femoral pulses in a neonate is the classic presentation of critical coarctation of the aorta as the ductus arteriosus closes.

question: A 1-month-old baby is unwell for 2 days. Physical exam shows rapid and regular heart beats at 240/min, tachypnoea, slightly displaced apex beat, normal heart sounds and no significant heart murmur.
official_answer: Option F.

ai_answer.explanation: A regular, narrow-complex tachycardia with a heart rate around 240 bpm in an infant is characteristic of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT).

question: A 3-year-old girl is having low grade fever for 2 days. Mild runny nose and cough. In the past 12 hours, tachypnoea, rapid peripheral pulses at 170. Precordial exam shows cardiomegaly, unremarkable heart sounds, soft murmur at apex. Liver enlarged 3 cm below costal margin.
official_answer: Option B.

ai_answer.explanation: The development of heart failure (tachycardia, tachypnoea, cardiomegaly, hepatomegaly) following a viral prodrome is a classic presentation of acute myocarditis.

question: A 2-week-old preterm baby, 30 weeks of gestation. Increased RR, HR, displaced apical beat, HS normal, grade 3 continuous murmur at left upper sternal border.
official_answer: Option D.

ai_answer.explanation: A continuous, machine-like murmur at the left upper sternal border in a preterm infant with signs of heart failure is characteristic of a hemodynamically significant patent ductus arteriosus (PDA).

question: A 26 weeks preterm baby, presents with a cardiac murmur 3 days after birth, the murmur was systolic in left sternal border. The discovery of murmur coincides with the improvement of lung function after management. On examination, the cardiac apex is laterally displaced. There is also left sternal impulse, and murmur is noted. There was also hepatomegaly. CXR shows cardiomegaly and plethoric lung field. What is the likely diagnosis?
official_answer: PDA. Inhaled NO was often used in resp failure in preterm. This lowers pulmonary arterial pressure, leading to a rapid increase in left-to-right shunt, causing heart failure to set in early.

ai_answer.explanation: This scenario describes the classic presentation of a hemodynamically significant patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) in a preterm infant following a decrease in pulmonary vascular resistance.

question: A 5-year-old kid presents with coryzal symptoms for a few days. Recently he developed shortness of breath. Physical examination shows harsh breathing sounds.
official_answer: Option F. Harsh breathing sound = stridor?

ai_answer.explanation: The combination of coryzal symptoms followed by shortness of breath and harsh breathing sounds (stridor) is characteristic of croup (laryngotracheobronchitis).

question: Syncope many times within one day. Fever (?URTI) 1 week before. Heart rate 25 bpm and collapsed. Regained consciousness and heart rate 70 bpm. PE reveals right and left heart failure.
official_answer: Option E. Due to viral myocarditis.

ai_answer.explanation: Syncope with profound bradycardia (25 bpm) and subsequent heart failure following a viral illness is highly suggestive of complete heart block secondary to myocarditis.

question: Recurrent syncope triggered off by loud bell.
official_answer: Option A. The answer key suggests D/I? but specific stimuli like a loud sound can trigger seizures or, more classically, cardiac events in Long QT syndrome.

ai_answer.explanation: Syncope triggered by an auditory stimulus, such as a loud bell or alarm clock, is a classic presentation for congenital Long QT syndrome.

question: A 10-year-old boy with syncope, weakness and lethargy for 1 year, sun-tanned skin, low Na, high K.
official_answer: Option C.

ai_answer.explanation: The combination of syncope, weakness, hyperpigmentation (sun-tanned skin), hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia is the classic presentation of an adrenal crisis (Addison's crisis).

question: A 16-year-old boy has recurrent exercise induced syncope when playing basketball. History of murmur during infancy but defaulted FU. P/E: weak pulse, left thrusting apex, systolic thrill & ESM grade 4/6 over RUSB.
official_answer: Option B.

ai_answer.explanation: Exertional syncope with a weak pulse and an ejection systolic murmur radiating to the right upper sternal border (RUSB) are hallmark signs of severe aortic stenosis.

question: A 8-year-old boy with hearing impairment collapsed. Mother had ICD implanted. Elder brother also has hearing loss and ?collapsed before.
official_answer: Option A. The Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome refers to the autosomal recessive phenotype of congenital LQTS that is associated with profound sensorineural hearing loss and a high risk for sudden death.

ai_answer.explanation: The combination of congenital sensorineural deafness and syncope/sudden death in a family is characteristic of Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome, a form of Long QT syndrome.

question: 14/F, fell in hall after prolonged standing; dizzy and blackout. Did not take breakfast that morning.
official_answer: Option I.

ai_answer.explanation: Syncope associated with prolonged standing, especially with precipitating factors like missing a meal, is a classic presentation of vasovagal (neurocardiogenic) syncope.

question: Poor weight gain, weak femoral pulses, hepatomegaly 2 cm.
official_answer: Option B. Age is crucial here. If newborn: CoA. If older children: myocarditis with both left heart and right heart failure.

ai_answer.explanation: The combination of heart failure signs (poor weight gain, hepatomegaly) and weak femoral pulses is the classic presentation of coarctation of the aorta in infancy.

question: Boy collapsed and resuscitated. Rapid regular pulse at ?210–240 bpm. Mildly displaced apex.
official_answer: Option D.

ai_answer.explanation: Collapse with a very rapid, regular heart rate in the range of 210-240 bpm is characteristic of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT), the most common tachyarrhythmia in children.

question: Fever, cardiomegaly, ?soft murmur, mild hepatomegaly.
official_answer: Option F. The answer key on page 17 says E, but the annotations on page 16 suggest F. F is a better fit for non-specific heart failure with fever.

ai_answer.explanation: The presentation of fever with signs of heart failure (cardiomegaly, hepatomegaly) without clear risk factors for endocarditis is highly suggestive of acute myocarditis.

question: Continous murmur.
official_answer: Option A.

ai_answer.explanation: A continuous, machine-like murmur is the pathognomonic finding of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA).

question: Apex displaced, PSM at LLSB, 3 cm hepatomegaly.
official_answer: Option C.

ai_answer.explanation: A pansystolic murmur (PSM) at the left lower sternal border (LLSB) with signs of volume overload and heart failure (displaced apex, hepatomegaly) is characteristic of a large ventricular septal defect (VSD).

question: 3 days old. Poor feeding. Mild cyanosis. Weak peripheral pulses. Parasternal heave. Apex at 6th intercostal space, 1 cm lateral to mid-clavicular line. Single S2. 3/6 ESM over LSB. Hepatomegaly 5 cm below costal margin.
options: Large VSD with moderate pulmonary hypertension
Ebstein's anomaly of the tricuspid valve
Obstructed total anomalous pulmonary venous drainage
official_answer: Option F.

ai_answer.explanation: The presentation of cardiogenic shock (weak pulses, hepatomegaly), cyanosis, and a single S2 in the first few days of life is classic for duct-dependent systemic circulation, as seen in hypoplastic left heart syndrome.

question: 11/F. Cyanosis. Clubbing of fingers and toes. Parasternal heave. Accentuated S2 3/6 ESM over LSB.
options: Large VSD with moderate pulmonary hypertension
Ebstein's anomaly of the tricuspid valve
Obstructed total anomalous pulmonary venous drainage
official_answer: Option J. The answer key on page 17 says H, but the features described, especially an accentuated S2, are more typical of Eisenmenger syndrome.

ai_answer.explanation: Chronic cyanosis with clubbing, a parasternal heave, and a loud (accentuated) P2 component of S2 are hallmark features of Eisenmenger syndrome, representing irreversible pulmonary hypertension.

question: 3 months old. Cyanosis. Parasternal heave. Single second heart sound. 3/6 ESM over LSB.
options: Large VSD with moderate pulmonary hypertension
Ebstein's anomaly of the tricuspid valve
Obstructed total anomalous pulmonary venous drainage
official_answer: Option H.

ai_answer.explanation: The combination of cyanosis, a parasternal heave (from RVH), a single S2, and an ejection systolic murmur in an infant is the classic presentation of Tetralogy of Fallot.

question: 7 day old infant with mild to moderate cyanosis, tachypnoea, cardiomegaly and hepatomegaly. 100% oxygen could not raise transcutaneous oxygen saturation. CXR shows prominent (? pulmonary) vascular markings.
options: Large VSD with moderate pulmonary hypertension
Ebstein's anomaly of the tricuspid valve
Obstructed total anomalous pulmonary venous drainage
official_answer: Option I.

ai_answer.explanation: Cyanosis with respiratory distress and a CXR showing pulmonary venous congestion (prominent vascular markings) is characteristic of obstructed total anomalous pulmonary venous drainage (TAPVD).

question: 1 day old. Cyanosis. Right arm has higher SpO2 than lower limb. Loud and single second heart sound. Either grade 2 or 3/6 ESM over LSB.
options: Large VSD with moderate pulmonary hypertension
Ebstein's anomaly of the tricuspid valve
Obstructed total anomalous pulmonary venous drainage
official_answer: Option D.

ai_answer.explanation: Differential cyanosis (higher pre-ductal SpO2 in the right arm) is the pathognomonic sign of persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN) with right-to-left shunting across the ductus arteriosus.

question: 10 year-old boy has coryzal symptoms, complaining of central chest pain. Tachycardia and faint heart sounds.
official_answer: Option B.

ai_answer.explanation: Central chest pain following a viral (coryzal) illness, associated with tachycardia and muffled (faint) heart sounds, is a classic presentation of acute pericarditis, possibly with an effusion.

question: 15/F with long limbs and excessive joint flexibility. Sudden onset of chest pain during in school. P/E: reduced air entry in right hemithorax.
official_answer: Option A.

ai_answer.explanation: Sudden onset pleuritic chest pain and reduced air entry in a tall, thin individual (suggesting a marfanoid habitus) are classic for a spontaneous pneumothorax.

question: A boy has chest pain and dizziness repeatedly in PE lessons. Strong apical impulse with murmur.
official_answer: Option G.

ai_answer.explanation: Recurrent exertional chest pain and dizziness, along with a strong apical impulse, are highly suggestive of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HOCM), a key cause of sudden death in young athletes.

question: Febrile girl with productive cough and sputum, P/E: decreased air entry on lower left side.
official_answer: Option C.

ai_answer.explanation: Fever, productive cough, and focal decreased air entry are classic signs of pneumonia, which causes pleuritic chest pain due to inflammation of the pleura.

question: A boy complains of chest pain over the left lower chest wall for 4 days. The pain gets more and more severe. P/E: rash on chest wall.
official_answer: Option H.

ai_answer.explanation: Severe, localized chest wall pain followed by the appearance of a rash in a dermatomal distribution is the classic presentation of Herpes Zoster (shingles).

question:
A few month history of itchy rash in a toddler (~9 months) over the trunk, failure to thrive.
(a) Differential diagnoses and how to differentiate from history and physical examination.
(b) Management.
(c) How can the mother prevent atopy in the next child?
official_answer:
(a) Differential diagnoses: Atopic eczema - other atopic features, spares the diaper region. Scabies - intense itch, burrows in web space, widespread. Dermatophytosis - annular configuration, more scaly. Psoriasis, seborrheic dermatitis.
(b) Management: Topical steroid (or pimecrolimus if prolonged), emollient, oral antihistamine, bathroom care (soap substitute, warm water), wet wrap, soak and smear if severe; oral steroid if very severe.
(c) Breastfeeding.

ai_answer.explanation: The answer provides a comprehensive differential diagnosis and a standard, stepwise management plan for infantile atopic eczema, correctly identifying breastfeeding as a primary prevention strategy for atopy.

question:
A 14-year-old girl with SLE on steroid feels ?tingling and tenderness on left cheek. Physical examination finds reddish papules and vesicles only on the left cheek, not involving other part of body.
(a) What are the differential diagnoses?
(b) Investigations to confirm the diagnosis.
(c) Management and prognosis.
official_answer:
(a) Herpes zoster. D/dx: herpes simplex, atopic/contact dermatitis, ?discoid lupus.
(b) Vesicular fluid x PCR, viral culture.
(c) Consider lowering steroid dose. Oral acyclovir. Warn postherpetic neuralgia.

ai_answer.explanation: The unilateral, dermatomal vesicular rash in an immunosuppressed (on steroids for SLE) patient is classic for Herpes Zoster, and the suggested investigations and management are appropriate.

question:
A 3-year-old boy presents with recurrent itchy erythematous rash on flexural area. GP prescribed him topical medication with temporary relief but always recur. Get worse in dry winter season. Not associated with food intake. Now presents with pain and swelling over the lesion in left ankle. Exudative oozing.
(a) What is the most likely cause of the underlying condition? What caused the exacerbation? (2 marks)
(b) How would you manage his acute condition? (4 marks)
(c) How would you manage his chronic condition? (4 marks)
official_answer:
(a) Atopic dermatitis with impetiginization.
(b) NO topical steroid. Hygiene measures. Topical mupirocin cream.
(c) Bathroom care. Allergen avoidance. Emollient. Oral antihistamine. Topical steroid as mainstay.

ai_answer.explanation: The history is typical for atopic dermatitis, and the acute exudative oozing correctly identifies a secondary bacterial infection (impetiginization) requiring topical antibiotics before resuming steroids for chronic management.

question: 13/F webbed neck, shield chest. No breast development. Bicuspid aortic valve.
options: Constitutional delay of growth and puberty
official_answer: Option H. The combination of short stature, webbed neck, shield chest, and lack of secondary sexual development in a female is classic for Turner's syndrome.

ai_answer.explanation: This constellation of features, including cardiac anomalies like bicuspid aortic valve, is pathognomonic for Turner's syndrome (45,X0).

question: F/16 referred for short stature and poor weight gain. History of recurrent fever with abdominal pain and diarrhoea. Also complained about eye pain and blurred vision.
options: Constitutional delay of growth and puberty
official_answer: Option E. The gastrointestinal symptoms combined with short stature and extra-intestinal manifestations like uveitis point towards Crohn's disease.

ai_answer.explanation: Inflammatory bowel disease, particularly Crohn's, can cause growth failure and extra-intestinal manifestations such as uveitis in adolescents.

question: M/9 referred for short stature (<3rd percentile). Full term birth. Mid-parental height 150 cm (25th percentile). Satisfactory school performance with no complaint from teacher. Slow growth rate, pre-pubertal with delayed bone age. Baseline blood (CBC, L/RFT, TFT) all normal.
options: Constitutional delay of growth and puberty
official_answer: Option B. This is a classic history for constitutional delay, characterized by a normal birth weight/length, followed by a period of slow growth, delayed bone age, and a family history of similar patterns.

ai_answer.explanation: The key features are falling off the growth curve in early childhood, delayed bone age, and normal investigations, with eventual catch-up growth and puberty.

question: M/11 fat and short. Slight mental retardation. slanting palpebral fissure, flat nose, single palmar crease. Hypothyroid on thyroxine with good compliance.
options: Constitutional delay of growth and puberty
official_answer: Option G. The described dysmorphic features are characteristic of Down's syndrome (Trisomy 21).

ai_answer.explanation: The combination of specific facial features, single palmar crease, and intellectual disability is highly indicative of Down's syndrome.

question: Headache and bump into edge of doors frequently. MRI brain shows craniopharyngioma.
options: Constitutional delay of growth and puberty
official_answer: Option D. Craniopharyngioma, a suprasellar tumor, can cause bitemporal hemianopia (bumping into doors) and compress the pituitary gland, leading to growth hormone deficiency and short stature.

ai_answer.explanation: Craniopharyngioma commonly presents with visual field defects and pituitary hormone deficiencies, with growth hormone being the most frequently affected.

question: A boy with nephrotic syndrome was treated in China with medications. He has significant weight gain and buffalo hump.
official_answer: Option F. The treatment for nephrotic syndrome often involves high-dose corticosteroids, which can induce iatrogenic Cushing's syndrome, characterized by weight gain and a buffalo hump.

ai_answer.explanation: The clinical features of central obesity and buffalo hump in the context of steroid treatment for nephrotic syndrome are classic for iatrogenic Cushing's syndrome.

question: Almond shaped eyes, hunger for food. History of IAA and VSD.
official_answer: Option A. Almond-shaped eyes and hyperphagia (insatiable hunger) are hallmark features of Prader-Willi syndrome.

ai_answer.explanation: This genetic disorder is characterized by hypotonia in infancy followed by hyperphagia and obesity in childhood, along with distinct facial features.

question: A 9-month-old Indian moved to Hong Kong at 6 months. He has coarse hair, cold and dry skin, frontal bossing, umbilical hernia, myxoedema, and developmental delays.
official_answer: Option G. This constellation of signs and symptoms is classic for congenital hypothyroidism, which may not have been screened for at birth.

ai_answer.explanation: Coarse features, dry skin, umbilical hernia, and developmental delay are all characteristic manifestations of untreated congenital hypothyroidism.

question: A primary 6 student, with good academic grades, doesn't like exercise, but likes to eat sugary foods. He is tall without any dysmorphic features.
official_answer: Option E. In the absence of dysmorphic features or endocrine abnormalities, obesity resulting from a caloric surplus (high sugar intake, low exercise) is classified as simple or exogenous obesity.

ai_answer.explanation: This diagnosis is made by excluding genetic, endocrine, or syndromic causes of obesity in a child with a history of excessive caloric intake and sedentary lifestyle.

question: A girl, whose diet is not particularly unhealthy fatty has obesity. Some family members have obesity too, one of whom has BMI of 30.
official_answer: Option D. A strong family history of obesity suggests a genetic predisposition, pointing towards familial obesity.

ai_answer.explanation: Familial obesity reflects the interplay of genetic susceptibility and shared environmental factors contributing to weight gain.

question: A 18-month-old baby had loose stool and vomit for 2 days. She just came back from China and her father also had diarrhoea when they were still in China. (a) What are the differential diagnoses and what further history will you obtain? (b) What physical signs will you look for for your management and what investigations will you order? (c) If she is 5% dehydrated, discuss the management principle.
official_answer: (a) Differentials: Gastroenteritis, Food poisoning, UTI, Hepatitis, etc. History: Symptom onset/characteristics, vomiting details, dehydration severity, associated symptoms, travel/contact history (TOCC), diet, vaccination. (b) Physical signs: General (weight, conscious state), Hydration status (skin turgor, mucous membranes, fontanelle), GI exam (mass, guarding), Cardiopulmonary exam. Investigations: Blood tests (CBP, RFT, electrolytes), Stool examination (pH, culture, microscopy). (c) Management: Rehydration is key, preferably with oral rehydration therapy (ORT). IV therapy is for severe dehydration or failed ORT. Aim to replace deficit + maintenance + ongoing losses. Early reintroduction of normal diet is recommended; antibiotics are not usually needed for viral GE.

ai_answer.explanation: The approach correctly prioritizes assessing for infectious gastroenteritis given the travel and family history, evaluating hydration status, and managing with oral rehydration as the first-line treatment.

question: A 6-month-old boy, 2-day history of vomiting and watery diarrhoea, febrile, weaker sucking than before, a bit dull. (a) Differential diagnoses. (3 marks) (b) Investigations for diagnosis and management. (4 marks) (c) Management. (3 marks)
official_answer: Answers similar to previous years. Key points are: DDx includes gastroenteritis, sepsis, UTI. Investigations include FBC, electrolytes, stool/urine/blood cultures. Management focuses on assessing and correcting dehydration (usually with ORS), supportive care, and monitoring.

ai_answer.explanation: In a febrile and dull infant with vomiting and diarrhea, it is crucial to consider and investigate for serious bacterial infections like sepsis and UTI in addition to viral gastroenteritis.

question: A 6-month-old boy with vomiting and diarrhoea for several days. Been bottle fed since birth. Sunken fontanelle, dry mucous membranes on examination. (a) Differential diagnoses. (b) Investigations and management for acute episode. (c) After discharge, the boy continues to have loose stools. The mother asks you if she should change to another formula. How would you counsel her?
official_answer: (a), (b) are similar to previous years (DDx: GE, sepsis; Ix: FBC, U&E, cultures; Mgt: Rehydration). (c) This is likely post-gastroenteritis syndrome with temporary lactose intolerance. Diagnosis is suggested by frothy, acidic stool (pH <6.0, reducing substances >0.5%). Management involves a brief switch back to ORT for 24 hours, then reintroduction of normal diet/formula, which is usually successful. A special formula is not typically required.

ai_answer.explanation: The management of post-gastroenteritis syndrome correctly identifies transient lactase deficiency and advises against unnecessary long-term formula changes, emphasizing gradual reintroduction of the normal diet.

question: A 2-year-old girl presents with vomiting and diarrhoea for several days. She is febrile. The stool contains some mucus and blood. She has travelled to mainland China 1 week before. Her 5 year old brother is also having diarrhoea, but milder. (a) What is the likely diagnosis and causative pathogens? (b) Assessment and investigations. (c) Management.
official_answer: Answers similar to previous years. (a) Likely diagnosis is infectious gastroenteritis (dysentery) given the bloody/mucoid stool. Causative pathogens could be bacterial (e.g., Shigella, Salmonella, Campylobacter, E. coli) or parasitic (e.g., Entamoeba). (b) Assessment for dehydration and systemic toxicity. Investigations must include stool culture and microscopy. (c) Management is rehydration, with consideration for antibiotics based on pathogen and severity.

ai_answer.explanation: The presence of blood and mucus (dysentery) with a relevant travel history necessitates stool culture to identify a bacterial pathogen and guide appropriate antibiotic therapy.

question: A 18-month-old boy presented with fever of 39°C and 2 times vomiting and 10 times diarrhoea for 2 days. (a) What are your two differential diagnoses and what are the history and physical signs that help you differentiate the two causes? (b) What are the investigations for the appropriate diagnoses? (c) What management will you offer after you make the diagnosis?
official_answer: (a) DDx: Gastroenteritis and Meningoencephalitis. Differentiating features for meningoencephalitis include very high fever, irritability/dullness, non-blanchable rash, seizures, and signs of increased ICP (bulging fontanelle). (b) Ix: WCC, ESR/CRP, L/RFT, blood/stool/urine cultures, and LP if meningoencephalitis is suspected. (c) Mgt: Admit, supportive care, rehydration therapy (oral or IV), vitals monitoring, and antibiotics if a bacterial cause is identified or suspected.

ai_answer.explanation: In a young child with high fever and GI symptoms, it is critical to differentiate simple gastroenteritis from more severe systemic infections like meningoencephalitis, which requires a lumbar puncture for diagnosis.

question: A 2-year-old boy is admitted for vomiting 6 times and diarrhoea 7 times. Cannot tolerate food or fluid. On examination the boy has reduced skin turgor, dry mucosa, lethargic and tired-looking. Pulse is 120. BP 84/42. Capillary refill normal (less than 2 sec). (a) What are the likely differential diagnosis? (2 marks) (b) What is the hydration status? (1 mark) (c) What is your acute management? (5 marks) (d) His mother asks you about feeding issues, including milk feeding. What is your advice? (2 marks)
official_answer: (a) Gastroenteritis, Addison disease. (b) Moderate (6-9%) dehydration. (c) IV rehydration based on body weight and serum sodium. (d) Resume feeding as tolerated once rehydrated. There is no need for a special formula. Can continue milk feeding, but may switch to soy-based milk if post-GE lactose intolerance develops.

ai_answer.explanation: The clinical signs indicate moderate dehydration requiring IV fluid resuscitation, followed by early re-feeding with the child's usual diet to promote gut recovery.

question: Peter, 5 year old with GE picture 12 times diarrhoea and 10 times vomiting. Lethargic, marked reduction in skin turgor and sunken eyeballs. Cold and mottled peripheries with weak pulses. Capillary refill at 5 seconds. Systolic BP 87 mmHg. Pulse 190/min. ABG given with reference range: low pH (7.14), low PaCO2, low HCO3, Na 120, K normal. Due to collapsed vein, IV catheter could not be put in therefore intraosseous catheter is put in. (a) What is the degree of dehydration? (1 mark) (b) What is the pathophysiological state the child is in? (1 mark) (c) Name 2 abnormalities. (2 marks) (d) What is the most appropriate type of fluid you will use and what is the amount of fluid you will give the child immediately? (2 marks) (e) Assume 10 kg body weight, MO wants to correct sodium from 120 to 130 mmol/L over the next 24 hours, what is the sodium required for the correction? Explain your calculation. (2 marks) (f) The child is stabilized and can tolerate oral rehydration solution (ORS), what are the two essential components of it and why are they essential? (2 marks)
official_answer: (a) Severe dehydration (>10%). (b) Hypovolemic shock. (c) Metabolic acidosis, hyponatremia. (d) IV Normal Saline (NS), 20mL/kg bolus. (e) Total sodium required is ~220mmol (deficit + maintenance). Calculation: Na deficit = (target Na - actual Na) * TBW + ongoing losses. (f) Essential components are electrolytes (isotonic/slightly hypotonic) and glucose. Electrolytes replenish losses, and glucose facilitates sodium and water absorption via the SGLT1 co-transporter.

ai_answer.explanation: This case of severe dehydration with hypovolemic shock requires immediate resuscitation with an isotonic fluid bolus (NS 20mL/kg) and careful correction of hyponatremia and metabolic acidosis.

question: About gastroenteritis, which of the following is correct?
options: Must give IV fluids for rehydration
Usual diet can only be continued after completely improved
official_answer: Option C. Breastfeeding should be continued during episodes of gastroenteritis as it provides hydration, nutrition, and immunological benefits.

ai_answer.explanation: Continuing breastfeeding during gastroenteritis is crucial as it reduces the severity and duration of illness and supports the infant's hydration and nutritional status.

question: A 2 (or 3)-month-old boy presents with recurrent non-bilious vomiting.
official_answer: Option A. The classic presentation of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is projectile, non-bilious vomiting in an infant aged 3-6 weeks.

ai_answer.explanation: Forceful, non-bilious vomiting in this specific age group is highly suggestive of hypertrophic pyloric stenosis until proven otherwise.

question: A 15-month-old child is unresponsive by parents at home, fever with persistent watery stools 6-7 times in the past 24 hours. No blood or mucous. On arrival to A&E Department, he is comatose with flexion response to pain. Capillary refill is more than 4 seconds. HR is 180/min. RR 50/min. What is the most likely diagnosis?
official_answer: Hypovolaemic shock.

ai_answer.explanation: The combination of unresponsiveness, tachycardia, tachypnea, and prolonged capillary refill following significant fluid loss from diarrhea indicates severe dehydration leading to hypovolemic shock.

question: A 11-month-old boy presented with vomiting and diarrhoea (10 times) for 1 day. No bloody stool but with mucus. Mild fever 37.9°C. Physical exam shows dehydration picture (sunken fontanelle etc.) What is the most likely causative agent?
official_answer: Option E. Rotavirus is the most common cause of severe dehydrating gastroenteritis in infants and young children, especially in the 6 month to 2 year age group.

ai_answer.explanation: In an unvaccinated child of this age, rotavirus is the leading cause of acute, watery, dehydrating diarrhea, often preceded by vomiting and fever.

question: GE picture. Sunken eyeball and ?fontanelles. Very poor vital signs. H’stix 4.8 mmol/L. What is the immediate management?
options: ?IV half NS half D5 + K 10 mmol/L (?concentration not sure)
Oral rehydration solution (with some description on how to give it?)
official_answer: Option B. In a child with severe dehydration and poor vital signs (i.e., shock), the immediate management is rapid volume expansion with an isotonic crystalloid, such as a bolus of Normal Saline (NS).

ai_answer.explanation: The priority in hypovolemic shock is to restore intravascular volume quickly with an isotonic fluid like Normal Saline; dextrose-containing fluids are not used for initial bolus resuscitation.

question: Central abdominal pain which then migrates to RLQ.
official_answer: Option A. The classic presentation of acute appendicitis is periumbilical pain that localizes to the right lower quadrant (McBurney's point).

ai_answer.explanation: This migration of pain is due to the initial visceral irritation of the midgut appendix followed by somatic inflammation of the overlying parietal peritoneum.

question: A 14-year-old boy was admitted to the general paediatric ward with a complaint of recurrent central abdominal pain with vomiting. On examination he was confused. Examination of the chest and abdomen did not reveal any specific findings except deep sighing type breathing. He also had dry oral mucosa and decreased skin turgor.
official_answer: Option E. Abdominal pain, vomiting, confusion, dehydration, and Kussmaul breathing (deep, sighing) are classic signs of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA).

ai_answer.explanation: The combination of neurological changes, signs of severe dehydration, and compensatory hyperventilation for metabolic acidosis strongly suggests DKA.

question: A 2-year-old boy, complained of abdominal pain. The mother gave a history of the boy rolling over and over in bed but could not find a position of comfort. P/E: vague mass on right side of abdomen.
official_answer: Option H. Paroxysmal, colicky abdominal pain causing the child to draw up their legs, along with a palpable sausage-like mass, is characteristic of intussusception.

ai_answer.explanation: This clinical picture of severe, intermittent pain and a palpable abdominal mass in a toddler is classic for intussusception.

question: Teenage girl. Repeated upper abdominal pain after meal. Vomiting.
official_answer: Option J? The answer key suggests J (Peptic ulcer disease) or C (Biliary colic). Post-prandial epigastric pain is a feature of peptic ulcer disease.

ai_answer.explanation: Postprandial upper abdominal pain in an adolescent is a common presentation for peptic ulcer disease, often related to H. pylori infection.

question: 2 months old, FTT, recurrent projectile non-bile-stained vomitus after milk.
official_answer: Option B. Projectile non-bilious vomiting and failure to thrive (FTT) in an infant of this age are the hallmark signs of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.

ai_answer.explanation: This classic triad of age, projectile non-bilious vomiting, and poor weight gain is pathognomonic for pyloric stenosis.

question: A 6-month-old infant has frequent regurgitation of milk since last month of life and 2 chest infections. Vomitus contained coffee-ground materials.
official_answer: Option E. Frequent regurgitation, recurrent chest infections (aspiration), and coffee-ground emesis (esophagitis) are indicative of severe gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

ai_answer.explanation: The combination of typical reflux symptoms with complications like aspiration pneumonia and hematemesis points to a diagnosis of complicated GERD.

question: A 1-year-old girl developed low grade fever, frequent vomiting and several episodes of watery diarrhoea over last 24 hours. Physical examination shows significant dehydration.
official_answer: Option J. Acute onset of vomiting and watery diarrhea leading to dehydration in a 1-year-old is the classic presentation of viral gastroenteritis, most commonly caused by Rotavirus.

ai_answer.explanation: This clinical scenario is the archetypal presentation for rotavirus infection, a major cause of severe dehydrating gastroenteritis in this age group.

question: A 7-month-old infant intermittent crying episodes, pallor and vomiting. Fresh blood with mucus was detected on rectal exam.
official_answer: Option F. The triad of intermittent colicky pain, vomiting, and 'red currant jelly' stool (blood and mucus) is classic for intussusception.

ai_answer.explanation: Paroxysmal crying spells with pallor and the finding of blood and mucus in the stool are highly specific for intussusception in an infant.

question: 9 months old. Repeated non-bilious vomiting since 1 month old. Poor weight gain. P/E normal. Catching up since last month.
official_answer: Pyloric stenosis is unlikely as there is catching up. I think it is GERD, as the condition improves and usually resolves by the end of the first year of life.

ai_answer.explanation: The history of vomiting with recent improvement and 'catching up' on growth is characteristic of physiological gastroesophageal reflux (GER), which typically resolves as the infant matures.

question: Baby with fever for 2 days, bulging fontanelle, hypotensive, poor capillary refill.
official_answer: Option B. The combination of fever, bulging fontanelle (a sign of increased intracranial pressure), and signs of shock (hypotension, poor perfusion) is highly suggestive of bacterial meningitis.

ai_answer.explanation: This triad represents a pediatric emergency, as a bulging fontanelle in a febrile, septic-looking infant is considered meningitis until proven otherwise.

question: Polydipsia (+ ?weight loss), abdominal pain and vomiting recently. Lethargic and dehydrated, deep sighing breathing.
official_answer: Option G. Polydipsia, dehydration, lethargy, and Kussmaul respirations (deep, sighing breathing) are classic signs of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA).

ai_answer.explanation: This constellation of symptoms is pathognomonic for DKA, representing osmotic diuresis, volume depletion, and respiratory compensation for severe metabolic acidosis.

question: A 2.5-year-old girl has vomiting over 3 ?days/weeks/months. Unsteady gait, frequent bumping into furniture. Headache and vomiting. Mother notice she has a squint in her left eye.
official_answer: Option H. The combination of chronic vomiting, headache, ataxia (unsteady gait), and a new cranial nerve palsy (squint) points to a space-occupying lesion in the posterior fossa.

ai_answer.explanation: These neurological signs are red flags for an intracranial mass, with posterior fossa tumors being common in this age group and causing these specific symptoms.

question: A 6-month-old infant has severe intermittent crying and vomiting for ?1 day / days. Vague right abdominal mass. PR fresh blood and mucus.
official_answer: Option E. The classic triad of colicky abdominal pain, a palpable abdominal mass, and bloody/mucoid stool is pathognomonic for intussusception.

ai_answer.explanation: This presentation of paroxysmal crying, a sausage-shaped mass, and 'red currant jelly' stool is the textbook description of intussusception.

question: A 3-day-old infant presents with frequent bilious vomiting. Abdominal x-ray shows dilated gastric bubble.
official_answer: Option C. Bilious vomiting in a neonate is a surgical emergency until proven otherwise. The 'double bubble' sign (dilated stomach and proximal duodenum) on X-ray is classic for duodenal atresia.

ai_answer.explanation: Bilious emesis in the first few days of life combined with the characteristic 'double bubble' sign on abdominal radiograph confirms a diagnosis of duodenal atresia.

question: Blood tests show high lipid profile, high ferritin.
official_answer: Haemophagocytic lymphocytosis

ai_answer.explanation: Hyperferritinemia and hypertriglyceridemia are key diagnostic criteria for hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH), a syndrome of severe hyperinflammation.

question: 12/M, history of HbH disease, present with recurrent attacks of RUQ pain.

question: A girl studying primary school took a large amount of fruit juice and passed loose stool.

question: 4/M, from a fisherman family. Presented with 9 months of abdominal pain and constipation. Hb 9.9, MCV 72 fL. Smear shows basophilic stripping.

question: 13/M, Periumbilical pain. Pain after taking meal. Weight loss. Mucus in stool and diarrhoea.

question: 5/F, 2 year history of recurrent periumbilical pain, 1-2 daily bowel output with normal stool. No weight loss.

question: Best food for normal infant.

question: Recommendation for premature baby born at 30th week whose mother cannot breastfed.

question: Baby originally on cow's milk infant formula, now with acute GE and dehydration. Which one is the best to be given together with the rehydration therapy?

question: 18/M beta thalassaemia major presented with ankle oedema and SOB. On PE these is strong apical impulse, apex at 6th intercostal space, anterior axillary line. official_answer: (a) Diagnosis: Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCMP) due to iron overload. Treatment: Resume iron chelation, optimize Hb with transfusions, and manage heart failure (diuretics, ACEI/BB). (c) History: Details of thalassemia diagnosis/management, iron overload symptoms, previous workups. question: A 18-month-old girl presents with bruising for 2 weeks. No fever. P/E: bruising over trunk and lower limbs. Petechiae on face and body. Not pale, no organomegaly. Alert, active. question: A 4-year-old girl, one month progressive pallor and increase lethargy. Physical examination shows pallor and few petechiae over trunk and limb, and enlarged liver and spleen. (2 marks)

question: A 6-month-old baby is shown with an infected, red and swollen BCG scar. What is the abnormality shown in the upper limb?

question: A 6-month-old baby is shown with an infected, red and swollen BCG scar. A blood test is shown. Identify 3 abnormalities in the blood test.

question: A 6-month-old baby is shown with an infected, red and swollen BCG scar. 2 CT abdomen scans are shown. Name the radiological abnormalities in CT 1 and CT 2.

question: A 6-month-old baby with an infected BCG scar has early morning aspirates showing AFB +ve and +ve for ZN stain, and a skin biopsy showing AFB. What is the aetiology causing the infection?

question: A 6-month-old baby with disseminated Mycobacterium bovis infection has decreased IgG/A/M, decreased T cell subsets, and normal CD19+ B cell count. What is the diagnosis?

question: A 6-month-old baby is diagnosed with SCID. Further family history showed he has an elder brother who died of a similar disease. What is the likely inheritance?

question: A picture of an inflamed, oozing, angry looking BCG wound is shown. What is the causative agent of the axillary adenopathy? (1 mark)

question: Based on findings of prolonged ulceration and abscesses, what is the diagnosis? (1 mark)

question: Name the investigation to confirm the diagnosis of CGD. (2 marks)

question: The mother mentioned her younger brother died from recurrent infections at the age of 9. What is the mode of inheritance? (1 mark)

question: A 12-month-old child presents with pneumonia caused by pneumococci. Previous 2 episodes of pneumonia, one in 8 month, one in 10 month, in different lobes. Which of the following investigations is the most appropriate?

question: Which of the following not sign of immunodeficiency?
